title: Abram and Lot Separate
shortSummary: Genesis 13 recounts the return of Abram and Lot from Egypt and the subsequent separation of their households due to increasing wealth and strife among their herdsmen. God reaffirms His covenant promise to Abram, promising him the land and numerous descendants, highlighting faith and obedience amid challenges.

keyCharacters.name: Abram
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch called by God, wealthy in livestock and possessions, who demonstrates faith and peacemaking by allowing Lot to choose the land first.

keyCharacters.name: Lot
keyCharacters.description: Abram’s nephew who travels with him but chooses the fertile plain of Jordan, eventually settling near the wicked city of Sodom.

definitions.definition: Men who tended and managed the livestock, whose disputes in this chapter lead to the separation of Abram and Lot.
A sacred place for worship and sacrifice, symbolizing Abram’s devotion and communication with God.
A fertile region east of the Jordan River, noted here as well-watered and desirable land before the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.
Indigenous peoples living in the land of Canaan at the time, representing the existing inhabitants among whom Abram and Lot lived.

outline.heading: Abram’s Return and Prosperity
outline.description: Abram returns from Egypt with his family and possessions, becoming very wealthy. Both Abram and Lot have large flocks and herds, setting the stage for future conflict.

outline.heading: Conflict and Separation
outline.description: The land cannot support both Abram’s and Lot’s large herds together, causing strife between their herdsmen. Abram offers Lot the first choice of land, demonstrating humility and peace.

outline.heading: God’s Promise to Abram
outline.description: After Lot separates, God reaffirms His covenant, promising Abram all the land he can see and countless descendants, encouraging him to explore and claim the land.

outline.heading: Abram Settles at Hebron
outline.description: Abram moves his tent to the plain of Mamre near Hebron and builds an altar, signifying his continued worship and faithfulness to God.

application: Pursue peace and humility in relationships, even when conflicts arise over resources or differences.
Trust in God’s promises and timing, especially when circumstances seem challenging or uncertain.
Respond to God’s guidance by actively stepping out in faith, as Abram did by moving and building an altar.
Recognize the importance of worship and calling on the name of the Lord as a foundation for life’s decisions.

keyVerses.text: And Abram said unto Lot, Let there be no strife, I pray thee, between me and thee, and between my herdmen and thy herdmen; for we be brethren.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Abram’s peacemaking spirit and his recognition of family unity over material disputes.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Abram, after that Lot was separated from him, Lift up now thine eyes, and look from the place where thou art northward, and southward, and eastward, and westward: For all the land which thou seest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed for ever.
keyVerses.significance: God’s reaffirmation of His covenant promise to Abram, assuring him of the inheritance of the land and his descendants.

keyVerses.text: Arise, walk through the land in the length of it and in the breadth of it; for I will give it unto thee.
keyVerses.significance: God’s command to Abram to explore and claim the land demonstrates active faith and obedience.
